properties.name: Louisa Boren Park
properties.location_description: Start of the walk, located at 15th Avenue E and E Galer St/E Garfield St
properties.sense_explanation: Honors Louisa Boren, one of Seattle's earliest citizens and founders; contains historic trees moved from Denny Park.

properties.name: Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery
properties.location_description: On E Howe Street, north side of the road, west of Federal Ave E
properties.relative_distance: Walk north one block on 15th Ave E, then west on E Howe St.
properties.sense_explanation: Cemetery for Civil War veterans, including Union and Confederate soldiers, reflecting a specific historical period and its participants.
properties.rhetorical_usage: To get a feel for the layout of the tombstones, walk to the obelisk...

properties.name: Streissguth Gardens
properties.location_description: West of 10th Avenue E, accessed by descending 70 steps from E Blaine Street
properties.relative_distance: Side trip: From 10th Ave E & E Blaine St, walk west and descend steps.
properties.sense_explanation: A family-started garden now owned by the city, described as a 'little urban oasis,' implying peace and community care.

properties.name: Leary Mansion (Office of the Bishop)
properties.location_description: On 10th Avenue E, north of E Highland Drive, former home of John Leary
properties.relative_distance: Walk south on 10th Ave E from E Blaine St.
properties.sense_explanation: Former home of prominent citizen John Leary, later Red Cross HQ, then Episcopal Diocese; its 'lovely sandstone' signifies its grandeur.

properties.name: Sam Hill Mansion
properties.location_description: North side of E Highland Drive, just past Broadway E, former home of Samuel Hill
properties.relative_distance: South on 10th Ave E, then west on E Highland Drive past Broadway E.
properties.sense_explanation: Built by railroad executive Samuel Hill with 10-ft thick concrete walls, possibly to host royalty, showcasing grand aspirations and unique features.
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'walls are 10 feet thick... reinforced with massive steel rails,' 'rooftop garden... park-like setting.'

properties.name: Horace Chapin Henry Property
properties.location_description: Northwest corner of Harvard Avenue E and E Prospect Street, former estate site
properties.relative_distance: Follow E Highland Dr curving left, then south on Harvard Ave E to E Prospect St.
properties.sense_explanation: Site of former grand estate, donated for a library, then sold to fund current library branch (Susan J. Henry Branch), showing evolving use.
properties.rhetorical_usage: estate... all of which were demolished and eventually replaced

properties.name: Garry Oak Tree (in Harvard-Belmont Historic District)
properties.location_description: On the corner of Belmont Place E and Belmont Avenue E
properties.relative_distance: West on E Prospect St, follow Prospect to Belmont Pl E, then south to Belmont Ave E.
properties.sense_explanation: Washington's 'lone native oak,' a rare species this far north, surviving since at least 1928 amidst urban development.

properties.name: Cornish College of Arts (Kerry Hall)
properties.location_description: E Roy Street at Harvard Avenue E
properties.relative_distance: East on E Roy Street to Harvard Ave E.
properties.sense_explanation: Founded by Nellie Cornish, building designed to inspire students with names of famous artists, reflecting aspirations for arts in Seattle.
properties.rhetorical_usage: Building's appearance had 'both the restraint and freedom of Venetian, the Spanish, the Levant, and even of Tibet.'

properties.name: Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR) House
properties.location_description: East side of Harvard Avenue E at E Roy Street
properties.relative_distance: Adjacent, on the east side of Harvard Ave E at E Roy St.
properties.sense_explanation: A copy of George Washington's Mount Vernon, built by the Daughters of the American Revolution, representing historical reverence.
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'a copy of George Washington's home, Mount Vernon.'

properties.name: Loveless Building
properties.location_description: Northwest corner of E Roy Street and Broadway E
properties.relative_distance: Walk one block east on E Roy Street to Broadway E.
properties.sense_explanation: Described as a 'little bit of England,' designed by Arthur Loveless for local artists, with a private courtyard.

properties.name: Anhalt Apartments (on E Roy Street)
properties.location_description: On either side of E Roy Street, east of Broadway E, before 10th Ave E
properties.relative_distance: East on E Roy Street past Broadway E.
properties.sense_explanation: Known for 'elegant Capitol Hill apartments' with French Norman elements, creating a distinctive, house-like feel.
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'elegant Capitol Hill apartments with their French Norman inspired elements'

properties.name: "Millionaire's Row" Granite Hitching Post
properties.location_description: West side of the intersection of 14th Avenue E and E Roy Street
properties.relative_distance: Walk east on Roy St (path then street), south on 13th Ave E, east on E Mercer St, then north on 14th Ave E to E Roy St.
properties.sense_explanation: A 'rare sign of early Seattle,' a granite hitching post from the horse-drawn era, marking an entrance to 'Millionaire's Row.'

properties.name: Elbridge Amos Stuart Stepping Stone
properties.location_description: Southeast corner of E Valley Street and 14th Avenue E, close to the road
properties.relative_distance: One block north on 14th Ave E from E Roy St.
properties.sense_explanation: A granite stepping stone for carriages, owned by Carnation Milk's founder, another 'remnant of the city's early equestrian history.'
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'remnant of the city's early equestrian history'

properties.name: James A. Moore Mansion
properties.location_description: Southwest corner of 14th Avenue E and E Aloha Street
properties.relative_distance: One block north on 14th Ave E from E Valley St to E Aloha St.
properties.sense_explanation: Home of Capitol Hill's developer James A. Moore, who significantly influenced Seattle's formation.
properties.rhetorical_usage: Capitol Hill's developer James A. Moore.

properties.name: Volunteer Park Water Tower
properties.location_description: Inside Volunteer Park, near the south entrance from 14th Avenue E
properties.relative_distance: Walk north on 14th Avenue E into Volunteer Park.
properties.sense_explanation: A 1906 brick water tower essential for water supply, offering '106 steps up to an observation area with views of the city.'
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'cityâ€”best in winter when leaves don't block the scenery'

properties.name: Seattle Asian Art Museum
properties.location_description: East side of the main road in Volunteer Park, north of the water tower (original Seattle Art Museum building)
properties.relative_distance: Follow main road north from water tower in Volunteer Park.
properties.sense_explanation: Originally the Seattle Art Museum, now housing the Asian Art Museum, its design broke from traditional styles, signifying a progressive architectural approach.
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'Architectural historians consider it a very progressive design for its time'

properties.name: Volunteer Park Conservatory
properties.location_description: North of the Seattle Asian Art Museum, inside Volunteer Park
properties.relative_distance: Short walk north from the Asian Art Museum.
properties.sense_explanation: A 1912 glass conservatory, based on London's Crystal Palace, housing an 'enticing collection' that is 'ever-changing and always delightful.'

properties.name: Concrete Blocks of Retaining Wall (Former Streetcar Slabs)
properties.location_description: Retaining wall on the west side of 15th Avenue E, north of Volunteer Park's E Galer St exit
properties.relative_distance: Exit Volunteer Park to 15th Ave E, turn north.
properties.sense_explanation: Concrete slabs with holes are remnants of the former streetcar system from 1901, revealing layers of city's transportation history.
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'Note the concrete blocks... the trolley's steel rails sat atop and were attached to the slabs.'

properties.name: Lake View Cemetery
properties.location_description: West of 15th Avenue E, adjacent to Volunteer Park
properties.relative_distance: Across 15th Avenue E to the west (near end of walk).
properties.sense_explanation: One of Seattle's oldest and most diverse cemeteries, holding graves of key city settlers and notable figures, reflecting the city's varied history.
properties.rhetorical_usage: 'one of the oldest in the city and one of the most diverse'
